bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Walter J. Mandel, November 10, 1952

div1.p: Hench describes his research on Reed and his association with the preservation of Camp Lazear. He informs Mandel, a U.S. Customs official, that he will be transporting wood to the United States from Building No. 1, and inquires about the proper way to prepare and ship it.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Walter J. Mandel, November 10, 1952
div1.opener:
November 10, 1952
Mr. Walter J. Mandel
Acting Deputy Collector
Treasury Department
Bureau of Customs
St. Paul 1, Minnesota
My dear Mr. Mandel:
div1.p:
I am a consultant on the staff of the Mayo Clinic. For years I have had
as my hobby the story of the conquest of yellow fever. Undoubtedly you
have heard the name of Major Walter Reed, head of a U. S. Army commission
in Havana, Cuba, who carried on medical experiments which proved the rela-
tionship of mosquitoes to yellow fever. This is one of the great medical
discoveries of all time. I have frequently given lectures on the subject
and have made many trips to Cuba to visit the little spot, “Camp Lazear,”
where the experiments were done. Perhaps you will remember the play and
motion picture, “Yellow Jack,” a few years ago which dramatized these ex-
periments.

In connection with one of my visits to Cuba, I rediscovered Camp Lazear
in 1940 which had been “lost” for 40 years. Since 1940 I have been trying
to persuade the Cuban Government to memorialize “Camp Lazear” and the remains
of Reed's Building No. 1 (See the enclosed article, especially the photograph
on page 6). At long last the Cuban government is memorializing the spot.
They have extensively restored the little building and the camp will be dedicated
on December 3 in honor of Dr. Carlos Finlay whose theory, concerning mosquitoes
and yellow fever, Major Reed and his associates proved to be correct.

In the restoration of Building No. 1, to my regret instead of accepting my
advice and maintaining intact the little building as it now stands and con-
structing an outer protecting shell, the Cubans concerned with this project
made such an extensive restoration that what remains is more a replica than
a restoration. In this connection they tore down practically all of the original
walls which were specially constructed for the experiments and involved the use
of “tongued-and-grooved” boards. The base of the boards were affected by
termites but the rest of the boards were not, although there was some rotting.

Now here is my reason for writing you. The experiments of Major Reed and his
associates have captured the imagination of the United States, not only of the
medical profession but also of writers and laymen. It is my opinion that
there are a number of institutions and individuals who would be delighted to
have a small piece of this wood from the original building. I refer to the
little museum of the Walter Reed Hospital in Washington, the Surgeon General's
Museum in Washington, the museum at the University of Virginia where Reed and
others connected with yellow fever were graduated; General Walter Lawrence

Reed (Major Reed's son) and the son and daughter of Doctor Lazear, the martyr
who died during the experiments, and others. I have asked Doctor Nogueira to
save me some of this wood. How much he is saving I do not know but certainly
enough to fill a small packing case. I have been officially invited by the
Cuban Government to attend the dedication in Havana and to speak on December
3. Since I will be flying, I cannot bring this box back with me at that time,
but I should like to make the following inquires.

item.p:
1. How may I go about getting this wood admitted to the United States in the
safest way? Also the least expensive way. It was my thought that I would
have it boxed in Cuba, address it to myself and get in touch with the St. Paul
Customs Office, notifying them what the box contained so that there would be
either no customs or no significant customs duty. The building was built in
1900 so that the wood is 52 years old.

I propose to give some of these boards to be displayed “as is” to demonstrate
their special construction which was described by Reed, the double-thickness
wood, the tongued-and-grooved boards, etc. From some of the wood I propose
to have small souvenirs made, paper weights with a little bronze identifica-
tion plate, pen holders or some such. All of this will be entirely non-
commercial and will be done completely at my own personal expense with no
recompense of any sort. It is merely a sentimental gesture on my part and
a demonstration of my great interest in this particular phase of medical history.

list.item:
2. Will there be any sanitary precautions that have to be taken? I don't
believe that Cuban termites are any different from American termites and of
course we will select wood which is as sound as possible. Need I have the
wood treated in any way before it is sent?

3. Would some notation or letter or other insignia from your office, a copy
of which could be tacked to the box in a heavy envelope or fastened to the box
by a heavy tag, expedite the passage of this box through the American customs?
The box could be inspected of course in the usual way.

4. How should the box be sealed so that it can be properly inspected by
your associates? Ordinarily, I suppose they would merely nail the box shut
in the usual way.

5. Do you have a representative in Cuba that could inspect the material be-
fore it is shipped from Cuba to me and expedite matters in that way?

div1.p:
I would appreciate very greatly your early attention to this matter as I will
be going to Cuba in about three and a half weeks from now, about December 1.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
